etymologies: Old English fēawe, fēawa, of Germanic origin; related to Old High German fao, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin paucus and Greek pauros ‘small’

notes.text: Fewer versus less: strictly speaking, the rule is that fewer, the comparative form of few, is used with words denoting people or countable things (fewer members; fewer books; fewer than ten contestants). Less, on the other hand, is used with mass nouns, denoting things that cannot be counted (less money; less music). In addition, less is normally used with numbers (less than 10,000) and with expressions of measurement or time (less than two weeks; less than four miles away). But to use less with count nouns, as in less people or less words, is incorrect in standard English

examples.text: may I ask a few questions?

definitions: used to emphasize how small a number is

examples.text: sewing was one of her few pleasures
a population of fewer than two million
ask which products have the fewest complaints

shortDefinitions: emphasizing small size of group of people etc.

But to use less with count nouns, as in less people or less words, is incorrect in standard English

definitions: a small number of people or things

examples.text: I will recount a few of the stories told me
there are hundreds of applicants but only a few are selected
many believe it but only a few are prepared to say so

definitions: used to emphasize how small a number of people or things is

examples.text: few thought to challenge these assumptions
he was one one of the few who survived
very few of the titles have any literary merit

shortDefinitions: emphasizing small size of group of people etc.

definitions: the minority of people; the elect

examples.text: art is not just for the few
a world that increasingly belongs to the few
